Item:  9.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Tatia Prieto, President, Prismatic Services 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Review and Accept the Custodial Services Operational Study 
	 
On June 19, 2014, the Board awarded a contract to Prismatic Services to conduct a custodial services operational efficiency study (Board Item 18.01).  Prismatic Services' approach to conducting this study included data collection and analysis on existing conditions (custodial staffing, standards, tools, equipment, supplies, training, hiring practices, supervision, etc.), customer satisfaction surveys, school site fieldwork, including site visits, activity observations, interviews with school site and District staff.  Their Custodial Services Operational Efficiency Study Report is attached.  Prismatic Services’ President, Tatia Prieto, will present their process, findings and recommendations to the Board of Trustees.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
As stipulated by the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board Clerk, and J. Manuel Herrera, Board Trustee
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Establish a Board Task Force Committee to Review Schools' Start Times
	 
	 
The American Academy of Pediatrics recognizes insufficient sleep in adolescents as an important public health issue that significantly affects the health and safety, as well as the academic success, of our nation’s middle and high school students.  A substantial body of research has now demonstrated that delaying school start times is an effective countermeasure to chronic sleep loss and has a wide range of potential benefits to students with regard to physical and mental health, safety, and academic achievement. 
	 
At the January 15th Board meeting, Trustee Biehl requested the Board to consider establishing a Task Force to review the research on moving school start times to a later start time (i.e. after 8:30 am) and the impact to bussing, extracurricular activities and the work and school day.  The Board appointed Trustee Biehl and Trustee Herrera to set guidelines for establishing the membership of the Task Force.
	 
The Board is requested to consider and approve a 16-member Task Force comprised of (2) Trustees, (2) administrators, (4) teachers, (4) parents and (4) students.  The composition of the Task Force should be a reflection of stakeholders that is based upon demographics distributed across the District.  A staff member from the Educational Services Department will facilitate the Task Force.
	 
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board approve a 16-member Task Force comprised of (2) Trustees, (2) administrators, (4) teachers, (4) parents and (4) students to review the impact on moving school start times to later in the day.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding 2015 California School Boards Association (CSBA) Delegate Assembly Election
		 
		 
		 
Attached please find the ballot material for election of a representative to the 2015 CSBA Delegate Assembly for our region. The Board is requested to vote for no more than five (5) candidates. Regardless of the number of vacancies, the Board of Trustees may cast no more than one vote for any one candidate.
		Election results from CSBA will be available no later than April 1, 2015, on CSBA's website. If there is a tie vote, a run-off election will be held.  All re-elected and newly elected Delegates will serve two-year terms beginning April 1, 2015, - March 31, 2017.
		 
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees vote for no more than five (5) candidates for submission of the Official 2015 Delegate Assembly Ballot to CSBA.

Item:  13.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Title III Plan and Budget for English Learners and Immigrant Students for the 2014-2015 School Year
		 
		 
		 
As required by the California Department of Education (CDE), school districts that receive Title III supplemental funds for English Learners (ELs) and immigrant students need to update their Title III Plan.
		 
A team of District Administrators and Associate Principals of Educational Development (APEDs) convened to review the needs, goals, and activities for English Learners (ELs). The team also aligned the EL programs and services with Title III supplemental funds.
		 
The Title III supplemental funds are used to meet the following goals:
Improve English language proficiency for English Learners
Provide high quality professional development for teachers of English Learners and immigrant students
Increase parent and community participation
Increase graduation rates
Notify parents annually on EL instructional program, alternative programs, reclassification criteria, expected rate of graduation for students in the program, and Title III annual measurable objectives for ELs
The proposed Title III Plan and Budget were reviewed by the English Language Development (ELD) chairpersons and the District English Learner Advisory Committee (DELAC) at their January 2015 meetings.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A 
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Title III
		 
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Title III Plan and Budget for English Learners and Immigrant Students for the 2014-2015 school year.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.05
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Assessment and Accountability, and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action to Approve the San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School’s Alternative Schools Accountability Model (ASAM) Application
		 
		 
		 
I. Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
On June 7, 2012, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) approved the renewal petition for the San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School (SJCCCS), for the required five-year term, pursuant to Education Code § 47607 (a) (1). The term of the charter began on July 1, 2012, and will end on June 30, 2017.  
		 
The SJCCCS provides its target population of “low income, high-risk” students, ages 17½ and older ("no age limit for registry"), an educational program for the completion of the high school diploma requirements and job skills training, including work experience. The SJCCCS operates at two San Jose locations, the Berger Street campus and the Senter Road campus. Based on the recently submitted P1 Attendance Report which averages the attendance over a four-month period (August 18th – December 5th), SJCCCS has an enrollment of approximately 372 students.
		 
The East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) received an application for participation in the Alternative Schools Accountability Model (ASAM) from the SJCCCS on January 12, 2015. The ASAM, approved under the California Public Schools Accountability Act, establishes the California Department of Education as the responsible entity for developing systems of accountability to which all schools shall be held. More specifically, Education Code § 52052 (h) required:
		 
The Superintendent, with the approval of the State Board of Education, shall develop an alternative accountability system for schools under the jurisdiction of the county board of education or a county superintendent of schools, community day schools, . . . and alternative schools serving high-risk pupils, including continuation high schools and opportunity schools.
		 
II. San Jose Conservation Corps’ ASAM Participation
The SJCCCS’s rationale for pursuing ASAM participation is to allow the school to gain a more accurate measure of its progress in educating low-income, high-risk students. Measures used by regular schools do not adequately assess SJCCCS’s student and school performance. SJCCCS administrators feel that the ASAM will provide a set of metrics, from which data can be generated to more accurately measure the good work the school is doing in its educational programs designed to create the successful completion of high school for its high-risk students.
  
ASAM schools receive an API score; however, they are not “included in the API rankings”.  Furthermore, these schools, “held accountable under the Academic Performance Index (API)” do “receive growth targets as all other schools” and must also meet the Federal Adequate Yearly progress (AYP) consistent with “all other schools”.
		 
III. District Administration's Recommendation for San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School
The State Board of Education requires that charter schools desiring participation in ASAM receive approval from the “local district governing board”. The San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School Board approved the ASAM application on January 8, 2015 (Attachment A).

Item:  13.06
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Fourth Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1, 2014, through December 31, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
		 
		 
		 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12, inclusive, shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
		 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
		 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from October 1, 2014, through December 31, 2014. 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None   
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering October 1, 2014, through December 31, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Weekly Bingo as a Fundraiser by Oak Grove High School Band Boosters (OGBB) and Facility Use Agreement  
	 
	 
At the Board Meeting of October 16, 2014, agenda item 13.02, the Board authorized the Oak Grove High School Band Boosters (OGBB) to solicit contributions or funds on District sites for the benefit of any District students, but the approval specifically excluded bingo.  Since then, the OGBB has obtained the required bingo permit from the San Jose Police Department.  
	 
Therefore, the Administration recommends that the Board authorize OGBB to include bingo as a fundraiser.   
	 
Also, OGBB is requesting to utilize the small gym at Oak Grove High School every Wednesday from 5:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. for bingo.  
	 
District’s Legal Counsel has confirmed that there is no law prohibiting bingo on school property.
	 
San Jose Municipal Code Chapter 6.16.250 Proceeds to be kept in separate funds – Use restrictions. (B) provides:
	 
“A portion of such proceeds, not to exceed ten present of the proceeds after the deduction for prizes, or five hundred dollars per month, whichever is less, may be used for rental of property, overhead, and administrative expenses, including the purchase of bingo equipment.” 
	 
In order to comply with the San Jose Municipal Code, the facility use fee agreed with the OGBB does not fully comply with the fee schedule in District Board Policy 1330 Use of School Facilities and Administrative Regulations 1330 Use of School Facilities.  (Policies are currently being revised to conform to the Civic Center Act.) 
	 
The Facility Use Agreement is attached and presented to the Board for review and/or approval to authorize OGBB use of the small gym at Oak Grove High School for the purpose of hosting bingo weekly.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Oak Grove Band Boosters to include bingo as a fundraiser and approve the Facility Use Agreement.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
	 
DESCRIPTION:
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: 
	 
                         Student A            Student B            Student C            Student D             Student E            
                         Student F            Student G            Student H            Student I              Student J            
                         Student K            Student L            Student M            Student N             Student O
                         Student P            Student Q           Student R             Student S             Student T
                         Student U            Student V           Student W            Student X             Student Y
                         Student Z            Student AA         Student AB           Student AC          Student AD
                         Student AE          Student AF        
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  20.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Authorizing Offer of Incentives to Certificated Staff for the Early Notification of Retirement
	 
	 
In an effort to recruit the most highly qualified teachers, the District must have the ability to hire staff as soon as possible for the 2015-2016 school year.  Neighboring districts will be hiring newly credentialed teachers, phase two student teachers and interns as early as January.  To be competitive, while remaining fiscally responsible, the District must have some indication of the actual teacher needs for the next school year.
	 
To assist in the successful recruitment of teachers, it is recommended that the Board authorize the offer of incentives to certificated staff for early notification of retirement.  The East Side Union High School District will provide certificated staff - ESTA bargaining unit members and administrators (funded by general fund) - with the opportunity to submit an irrevocable letter of retirement by March 6, 2015.  A one-time, monetary payment will be offered to certificated staff who submit their irrevocable letter within the specified timeline.  The criteria for this incentive would be as follows:
	 
     a) An irrevocable letter of retirement must be received by March 6, 2015.
	 
     b) The effective date of the irrevocable retirement must be no later than June 30, 2015.
	 
The East Side Teachers Association has been consulted and supports this recommendation.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As determined through attrition
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the one-time, monetary incentives for those certificated staff who submit by March 6, 2015, an irrevocable letter of retirement, effective no later than June 30, 2015.
